 [**2165-4-8**]
 Preliminary evaluation
 RV dysfunction
   Assessment and Plan
   36yo male with morbid obesity was admitted s/p cardiac arrest at home.
   1. s/p Arrest
   Etiology of his arrest is unclear and will be very difficult to assess
   given that he was unmonitored at the time of the event. Differential
   diagnosis includes pulmonary embolus given intraventricular conduction
   delay in lead V1, tachycardia, and hypoxia. Preliminary evaluation of
   echo appears to demonstrate RV dysfunction which would also be
   consistent for pulmonary embolus. Additional differential diagnosis
   includes ischemia, structural heart disease, and arrhythmia, although
   patient has no prior history of any of these abnormalities. An
   additional possibility includes a non-cardiac cause of hemodynamic
   instability resulting in a PEA arrest, although patient has no specific
   localizing symptoms or signs.
   - for evaluation of PE, will check CTA chest for evaluation of PE and
   coordinate CT head to evaluate for any intracranial bleed that would
   act as a contraindication to anticoagulation
   - follow-up fasting lipids in the AM
   - consider cardiac catheterization once more hemodynamically stable,
   although this seems less likely given that patient has minimmal other
   risk factors
   - follow-up echo read
   - consider EP consult in the AM and possible EPS once hemodynamically
   stable if no additional cause of VF arrest is found
   - continue cooling protocol via Arctic Sun
   - follow-up EEG and neuro recs per cardiac arrest protocol
   - replete electrolytes aggressively
   - follow-up blood and urine cultures
   2. Leukocytosis
   Etiology of his leukocytosis is most likely related to his Vfib arrest,
   although infection is also possible. Only localizing symptom at this
   time includes his UA that is suggestive of UTI, although no leuks or
   nitrates despite > 50 WBCs and bacteria.
   - resend UA and culture, treat with cipro if positive
   - follow-up blood cultures
   - follow-up CXR read
   3. Morbid Obesity
   Patient has morbid obesity and is currently undergoing outpatient
   evaluation for gastric bypass.
   - continue outpatient evaluation for gastric bypass procedure pending
   resolution of acute medical concerns
   4. Respiratory Failure
   Patient was intubated in the setting of cardiac arrest. Patient is on
   room air at baseline but does have a history of asthma and obstructive
   sleep apnea. No additional evidence of pneumonia or additional
   respiratory incident. ABG on current settings demonstrates adequate
   oxygenation but likely respiratory acidosis given slightly elevated
   PCO2.
   - continue to maintain intubation and sedation for adequate cooling
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Comments: NPO for now
   Glycemic Control:  Regular insulin sliding scale
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2165-4-8**] 04:36 AM
   Arterial Line - [**2165-4-8**] 04:37 AM
   18 Gauge - [**2165-4-8**] 06:02 AM
   Comments: -will likely need to place central line given need for
   multiple drips and possible hypotension in the setting of the cooling
   protocol
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care
   Comments:
   Communication: Patient discussed on interdisciplinary rounds , ICU
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:ICU
   ------ Protected Section ------
   Cardiology Teaching Physician Note
   On this day I saw, examined and was physically present with the
   resident / fellow for the key portions of the services provided. I
   agree with the above note and plans.
   I have also reviewed the notes of Dr(s). [**Name (NI) 399**].
   I would add the following remarks:
   Above discussed extensively with patient. Above discussed extensively
   with family member, next of [**Doctor First Name 372**] or health care proxy. I have discussed
   this plan with Dr(s). CCU team.
   DNR status discussed. Full code.
   Total time spent on patient care: 60 minutes of critical care time.
   Additional comments:
   Impression:  cardiopulmonary arrest in a 36-year old man with obesity
   and sleep apnea.  Diagnostic considerations are broad, but high on the
   list is pulmonary embolism and primary cardiac arrhythmia.  ACS is less
   likely given ECG, but is possible. Primary respiratory arrest is also a
   consideration.  Finally, this could have been a primary neurologic
   event given ?seizure, though the latter could have just been secondary
   to hypoxemia.
   Plan:
   1. Cooling protocol in progress
   2. Will interrupt #1 briefly to obtain head CT scan (r/o CNS bleed,
   structural brain abnormality, etc.)
   3. CTA chest to r/o PE
   4. Will decide on IV heparin after #2 and #3
   5. Echocardiogram to assess RV function in the meantime
   6. Repeat U/A
   7. Continuous EEG to r/o status epilepticus
   ------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 3494**], MD
   on:[**2165-4-8**] 11:04 ------
   Clinician:  Attending
   We attempted to perform head and chest CT scans today (see note above),
   but the patient is too large to fit on the scanner.  At this time, he
   is hemodynamically stable (mildly bradycardic [**2-11**] cooling), but his A-a
   gradient is very large and he is not ventilating well.
   At this time, I think that PE is much higher on the differential of his
   arrest than any structural brain abnormality.  I believe that he would
   be best served with IV infusion of heparin to treat presumed PE.  There
   is a small chance of intracranial hemorrhage with IV heparin if he has
   an underlying structural abnormality, but I don't think that's likely.
   I spoke to his [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) **] [**Name (NI) 6659**] (?sp), who is his HCP and made her aware
   of the situation and the risks.  She agreed that we should go forward
   with blood thinners "based on what we believe is going on".  She is
   aware of the potential risks.
   Total time spent:  60 minutes
   Patient is critically ill.
   ------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 3494**], MD
   on:[**2165-4-8**] 17:16 ------

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Pulmonary Embolism (PE): The patient's history of cardiac arrest, tachycardia, and hypoxia, along with the preliminary echo results showing RV dysfunction, suggest a high likelihood of PE. The patient's large A-a gradient and poor ventilation also support this diagnosis.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory acidosis and need for mechanical ventilation indicate a high risk of respiratory failure.
3. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis, elevated lactate levels, and possible UTI suggest a risk of sepsis.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and ongoing cardiac instability raise concerns about potential cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, or myocardial infarction.
5. Neurological Complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and possible seizure activity raise concerns about potential neurological complications, such as cerebral edema, intracranial hemorrhage, or status epilepticus.
6. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's morbid obesity and history of obstructive sleep apnea increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, and gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. Venous Thromboembolism (VTE): The patient's risk factors for VTE, including morbid obesity and immobility, suggest a risk of developing deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.
8. Infection: The patient's UTI and possible sepsis suggest a risk of infection, which can lead to septic shock and multi-organ dysfunction.
9. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's ongoing cooling protocol and possible cardiac instability raise concerns about potential electrolyte imbalances, such as hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, or hypomagnesemia.
10. Hemodynamic Instability: The patient's ongoing cardiac instability and possible sepsis suggest a risk of hemodynamic instability, which can lead to cardiac arrest, shock, or multi-organ dysfunction.

To address these potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and management in the ICU, including:

* Continued cooling protocol
* Monitoring of cardiac rhythm and hemodynamics
* Management of respiratory status
* Antibiotic therapy for possible UTI and sepsis
* Anticoagulation therapy for suspected PE
* Close monitoring of electrolyte levels and hemodynamic status
* Consideration of cardiac catheterization and echocardiogram to evaluate cardiac function
* Consultation with cardiology and neurology services as needed
* Ongoing communication with the patient's family and healthcare proxy.

   36yo male with morbid obesity was admitted s/p cardiac arrest at home.
   1. s/p Arrest
   Etiology of his arrest is unclear and will be very difficult to assess
   given that he was unmonitored at the time of the event. Differential
   diagnosis includes pulmonary embolus given intraventricular conduction
   delay in lead V1, tachycardia, and hypoxia. Preliminary evaluation of
   echo appears to demonstrate RV dysfunction which would also be
   consistent for pulmonary embolus. Additional differential diagnosis
   includes ischemia, structural heart disease, and arrhythmia, although
   patient has no prior history of any of these abnormalities. An
   additional possibility includes a non-cardiac cause of hemodynamic
   instability resulting in a PEA arrest, although patient has no specific
   localizing symptoms or signs.
   - for evaluation of PE, will check CTA chest for evaluation of PE and
   coordinate CT head to evaluate for any intracranial bleed that would
   act as a contraindication to anticoagulation
   - follow-up fasting lipids in the AM
   - consider cardiac catheterization once more hemodynamically stable,
   although this seems less likely given that patient has minimmal other
   risk factors
   - follow-up echo read
   - consider EP consult in the AM and possible EPS once hemodynamically
   stable if no additional cause of VF arrest is found
   - continue cooling protocol via Arctic Sun
   - follow-up EEG and neuro recs per cardiac arrest protocol
   - replete electrolytes aggressively
   - follow-up blood and urine cultures
   2. Leukocytosis
   Etiology of his leukocytosis is most likely related to his Vfib arrest,
   although infection is also possible. Only localizing symptom at this
   time includes his UA that is suggestive of UTI, although no leuks or

Summary:

The patient is a 36-year-old male who suffered a ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest at home and was admitted to the ICU. He has a history of morbid obesity, sleep apnea, and asthma. The patient is currently intubated and sedated, and is receiving mechanical ventilation with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 90%. He has a central venous catheter, an arterial line, and a urinary catheter in place.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis, with a white blood cell count of 18.1 K/uL, and elevated troponin-T levels, indicating possible cardiac injury. His cardiac enzymes, such as creatine kinase (CK) and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), are also elevated. His electrocardiogram (ECG) shows sinus tachycardia, normal axis, and intraventricular conduction delay in lead V1, which may indicate a pulmonary embolism.

The patient's imaging studies, including a computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest, are pending. The patient's cardiac function is impaired, with a right ventricular (RV) dysfunction observed on echocardiogram.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary Embolism: Given the patient's history of morbid obesity and sleep apnea, as well as the elevated troponin-T levels and ECG findings, pulmonary embolism is a strong consideration.
2. Cardiac Arrhythmia: The patient's VF arrest and ECG findings suggest that cardiac arrhythmia may be a contributing factor.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised, with a need for mechanical ventilation and a history of asthma and obstructive sleep apnea.
4. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and elevated troponin-T levels may indicate an underlying infection or sepsis.
5. Neurological Complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and possible hypoxemia may have caused neurological damage, which could lead to seizures, brain injury, or other complications.
6. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's morbid obesity and history of gastric bypass surgery may increase his risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as aspiration or bowel obstruction.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, the following plan has been developed:

1. Continue cooling protocol via Arctic Sun.
2. Obtain head CT scan to rule out CNS bleed or structural brain abnormality.
3. Perform CTA chest to rule out pulmonary embolism.
4. Decide on IV heparin after #2 and #3.
5. Repeat U/A to rule out UTI.
6. Continuous EEG to rule out status epilepticus.
7. Consider cardiac catheterization once hemodynamically stable.
8. Follow-up echo read.
9. Consider EP consult and EPS once hemodynamically stable.
10. Continue to replete electrolytes aggressively.

   - resend UA and culture, treat with cipro if positive

   evaluation for gastric bypass.
   - continue outpatient evaluation for gastric bypass procedure pending
   resolution of acute medical concerns

   room air at baseline but does have a history of asthma and obstructive
   sleep apnea. No additional evidence of pneumonia or additional
   respiratory incident. ABG on current settings demonstrates adequate
   oxygenation but likely respiratory acidosis given slightly elevated
   PCO2.
   - continue to maintain intubation and sedation for adequate cooling

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be determined:

Summary:

The patient is a 36-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after experiencing a ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest at home. He has a history of morbid obesity and is currently undergoing outpatient evaluation for gastric bypass. The patient's VF arrest is unclear in etiology, with differential diagnoses including pulmonary embolus, ischemia, structural heart disease, and arrhythmia. The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation, and he is being treated with antibiotics for possible infection.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary Embolism (PE): The patient's preliminary echo evaluation suggests RV dysfunction, which could be consistent with PE. This diagnosis should be further evaluated with a computed tomography angiogram (CTA) of the chest.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, which may be necessary to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation. However, the patient's history of asthma and obstructive sleep apnea increases the risk of respiratory complications.
3. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and UTI symptoms suggest the possibility of infection. Blood and urine cultures should be repeated, and the patient should be treated with antibiotics if the cultures are positive.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's VF arrest and RV dysfunction suggest the possibility of cardiac complications, including ischemia, structural heart disease, or arrhythmia. Further evaluation with an electrocardiogram (ECG) and echocardiogram is necessary to determine the extent of cardiac damage.
5. Neurological Complications: The patient's VF arrest increases the risk of neurological complications, including stroke, seizures, and cognitive impairment. The patient should be closely monitored for any neurological changes, and an electroencephalogram (EEG) should be performed to evaluate for any abnormal electrical activity.
6. Sepsis: The patient's fever, tachycardia, and tachypnea suggest the possibility of sepsis. The patient should be closely monitored for any signs of sepsis, and blood cultures should be repeated to evaluate for the presence of sepsis.
7. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension and decreased cardiac output increase the risk of organ dysfunction, including kidney and liver failure. The patient should be closely monitored for any signs of hypotension, and vasopressors should be considered if necessary.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and aggressive treatment to manage his complex medical conditions and prevent potential complications.

   diagnosis includes ischemia, which is not likely given no evidence on
   ECG, structural heart disease, and arrhythmia, although patient has no
   prior history of any of these abnormalities.  An additional possibility
   includes a non-cardiac cause of hemodynamic instability resulting in a
   PEA arrest, although patient has no specific localizing symptoms or
   signs.  Given patient's multiple medical problems including sleep
   apnea, asthma, and morbid obesity, a possible etiology of his arrest
   was arrest in the setting of hypoxia related to his
   obesity-hypoventilation, sleep apnea, and asthma, however less likely.

 IVCD and RV hypokinesis on ECHO yesterday

   yesterday, however based on pts weight it was unable to be completed.

   following rewarming

   of UTI on UA.  Trending down.

Summary:

The patient is a 36-year-old male with morbid obesity who was admitted to the ICU after cardiac arrest at home. He was intubated and sedated, and a cooling protocol was initiated. A transvenous pacing wire was placed, and heparin was started empirically. The patient's initial vital signs were bradycardic with a heart rate of 53 beats per minute, and slightly hypotensive with a blood pressure of 111/67 mmHg. He was also experiencing respiratory failure and was on a ventilator with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results showed evidence of leukocytosis, with a white blood cell count of 11.7 x 10^9/L. His troponin-T level was elevated at 1765 ng/L, and his lactate level was 0.7 mmol/L. His imaging studies showed evidence of mild left ventricular systolic dysfunction and mild right ventricular hypokinesis.

The patient's medical history is significant for morbid obesity, sleep apnea, asthma, and a recent cardiac arrest. He is currently undergoing outpatient evaluation for gastric bypass surgery.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to his morbid obesity and the need for continued mechanical ventilation.
2. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's cardiac arrest may have caused damage to his heart, leading to cardiovascular complications such as cardiac arrhythmias or heart failure.
3. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis may be due to an infection, which could worsen his condition if not treated promptly.
4. Hypoxia: The patient's respiratory failure may lead to hypoxia, which could worsen his cardiac condition.
5. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels may become imbalanced due to his prolonged hospitalization and the use of diuretics and other medications.
6. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's morbid obesity may increase his risk of gastrointestinal complications such as aspiration pneumonia or bowel obstruction.
7. Venous Thromboembolism: The patient's morbid obesity may increase his risk of venous thromboembolism, which could worsen his cardiovascular condition.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, it is essential to continue monitoring his vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies closely. He should be treated with antibiotics if an infection is suspected, and his respiratory failure should be managed with mechanical ventilation and other respiratory support measures.

Summary:

The patient is a 36-year-old male with morbid obesity who was admitted to the ICU following a cardiac arrest at home. He has a history of sleep apnea, asthma, and morbid obesity, which may have contributed to his arrest. The patient's cardiac arrest was likely due to hypoxia related to his obesity-hypoventilation, sleep apnea, and asthma, although a pulmonary embolism (PE) is also a possibility. He was intubated and sedated, and an Arctic Sun cooling protocol was initiated with vecuronium.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis, which may be related to his Vfib arrest or infection. He has a urinary tract infection (UTI) and is being treated with ciprofloxacin. His cardiac enzymes are mildly elevated, and an echocardiogram showed mild left ventricular systolic dysfunction and mild right ventricular hypokinesis.

The patient's medical plan includes continuing the Arctic Sun cooling protocol, intubation, and sedation for adequate cooling. He will also be repleted with electrolytes, and his blood and urine cultures will be followed. A cardiac catheterization may be considered once he is hemodynamically stable, and an electrophysiology (EP) consult may be considered in the morning.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and sedated, and his respiratory status may deteriorate if his ventilation is not adequately managed.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a UTI and is at risk for developing sepsis, which could lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac arrest may have been caused by a cardiac arrhythmia, and he may be at risk for developing further arrhythmias while in the ICU.
4. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's morbid obesity and sedentary lifestyle may have contributed to his risk of developing a PE, which could lead to further complications.
5. Infection: The patient has a UTI and is at risk for developing further infections while in the ICU.
6. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels may become imbalanced due to his medical treatment and underlying conditions, which could lead to further complications.
7. Organ dysfunction: The patient's underlying medical conditions, such as sleep apnea and asthma, may lead to organ dysfunction while he is in the ICU.

* Cardiovascular status: Mildly hypokinetic left ventricular function, a focal wall motion abnormality cannot be fully excluded, and mild global free wall hypokinesis of the right ventricle.
* Neurological status: Sedated and unable to assess neurological function due to sedation.
* Laboratory results: Leukocytosis, elevated troponin-T, and transaminitis.
* Imaging studies: ECHO showed mild left ventricular systolic dysfunction, mild right ventricular dilatation, and mild global free wall hypokinesis.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and there is a risk of worsening respiratory acidosis.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's bradycardic heart rate and mildly hypokinetic left ventricular function increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias.
* Sepsis: The patient has a UTI and is at risk of developing sepsis.
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient is at risk of developing DVT due to immobility and morbid obesity.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of sleep apnea and asthma, which may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Reperfusion injury: The patient's cardiac arrest and subsequent resuscitation may increase the risk of reperfusion injury.

The plan for the patient's care includes:

* Continue to maintain intubation and sedation for adequate cooling.
* Start rewarming the patient at 1 pm.
* Decrease the intensity of neuromuscular blockade and allow for some shivering to rewarm.
* Monitor for rewarming arrhythmias.
* Reassess neurological status.
* Follow up on EEG results.
* Treat with heparin empirically for DVT prophylaxis.
* Continue to monitor electrolyte levels and replete as needed.
* Follow up on blood and urine cultures.
* Trend CK levels daily.
* Continue to manage the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as needed.

   36yo male with morbid obesity was admitted s/p cardiac arrest at home.
   .
   1. s/p Arrest
   Etiology of his arrest is unclear and will be very difficult to assess
   given that he was unmonitored at the time of the event. Given patient's
   multiple medical problems including sleep apnea, asthma, and morbid
   obesity, a likely etiology of his arrest is arrest in the setting of
   hypoxia related to his obesity-hypoventilation, sleep apnea, and
   asthma. Additional differential diagnosis includes ischemia, structural
   heart disease, and arrhythmia, although patient has no prior history of
   any of these abnormalities. An additional possibility includes a
   non-cardiac cause of hemodynamic instability resulting in a PEA arrest,
   although patient has no specific localizing symptoms or signs.
   - ECG upon arrival to the floor
   - rule-out MI
   - check fasting lipids in the AM
   - consider cardiac catheterization once more hemodynamically stable
   - echo in the AM
   - consider EP consult in the AM and possible EPS once hemodynamically
   stable and has completed the arctic sun protocol
   - continue cooling protocol via Arctic Sun
   - replete electrolytes aggressively
   - follow-up blood and urine cultures
   .
   2. Leukocytosis
   Etiology of his leukocytosis is most likely related to his Vfib arrest,
   although infection is also possible. Only localizing symptom at this
   time includes his UA that is suggestive of UTI, although no leuks or
   nitrates despite > 50 WBCs and bacteria.
   - resend UA and culture, treat with cipro if positive
   - follow-up blood cultures
   - follow-up CXR read
   .
   3. Morbid Obesity
   Patient has morbid obesity and is currently undergoing outpatient
   evaluation for gastric bypass.
   - continue outpatient evaluation for gastric bypass procedure
   .
   4. Respiratory Failure
   Patient was intubated in the setting of cardiac arrest. Patient is on
   room air at baseline but does have a history of asthma and obstructive
   sleep apnea. No additional evidence of pneumonia or additional
   respiratory incident. ABG on current settings demonstrates adequate
   oxygenation but likely respiratory acidosis given slightly elevated
   PCO2.
   - continue to maintain intubation and sedation for adequate cooling
   .
   #. FEN: Follow and replete electrolytes. NPO for now. No IVF at

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 36-year-old male with morbid obesity who was admitted to the ICU after experiencing a cardiac arrest at home. The patient has a history of sleep apnea, asthma, and morbid obesity, which may have contributed to the arrest. The etiology of the arrest is unclear and will be difficult to assess given the patient's lack of monitoring at the time of the event.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Bradycardic with a heart rate of 53 beats per minute, blood pressure of 111/67 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient is receiving heparin infusion and has a central venous pressure (CVP) of 3 mmHg.
* Respiratory support: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 15 cmH2O.
* Laboratory results: The patient has leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 11.7 x 10^9/L, and elevated lactate acid levels of 0.7 mmol/L.
* Imaging: The patient's echocardiogram shows mild left ventricular systolic dysfunction, mild right ventricular dilatation, and mild global free wall hypokinesis.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory acidosis and elevated PCO2 levels may worsen if the patient's respiratory status is not closely monitored and managed.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's mild left ventricular systolic dysfunction and mild right ventricular dilatation may increase the risk of cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.
* Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and elevated lactate acid levels may indicate the presence of an underlying infection, which could worsen if not treated promptly.
* Hypothyroidism: The patient's elevated TCO2 levels may indicate hypothyroidism, which could worsen if not treated promptly.
* Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's morbid obesity and respiratory failure may increase the risk of nutritional deficiencies if not managed properly.
* Pressure ulcers: The patient's immobility and respiratory failure may increase the risk of pressure ulcers if not managed properly.

Based on the patient's condition, the following plan is recommended:

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, hemodynamic status, and respiratory function closely.
* Administer heparin infusion to prevent deep vein thrombosis.
* Continue to provide mechanical ventilation and adjust the settings as needed to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
* Monitor the patient's laboratory results, including leukocyte count, lactate acid levels, and thyroid function tests.
* Administer antibiotics if the patient's leukocytosis is determined to be caused by an infection.
* Consider referring the patient to a cardiothoracic surgeon for further evaluation and management of the patient's cardiac condition.
* Monitor the patient's nutritional status and provide supplemental nutrition as needed.
* Implement pressure ulcer prevention measures, such as turning and repositioning the patient every 2 hours, to prevent pressure ulcers.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a morbidly obese male who was intubated, sedated, and paralyzed. The patient's condition has deteriorated over the past 24 hours, with increasing acidemia and hypoxemia. The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.4°C
* Heart rate: 89 bpm
* Blood pressure: 97/50 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 28 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* SpO2: 100%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 8.5-11.3 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 12.1 g/dL
* Platelet count: 155-199 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.7-0.9 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 22-25 mg/dL
* Glucose: 92-104 mg/dL

The patient's medical history is significant for cardiac arrest, obesity, and hypoxemia. The patient is receiving various medications, including heparin, midazolam, fentanyl, and propofol.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemia and increasing acidemia may indicate a worsening respiratory failure.
* Cardiac arrest: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and ongoing hypoxemia and acidemia may increase the risk of recurrent cardiac arrest.
* Sepsis: The patient's increasing acidemia and hypoxemia may be indicative of sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ failure.
* Pulmonary edema: The patient's hypoxemia and increasing acidemia may increase the risk of pulmonary edema.
* Renal failure: The patient's increasing blood urea nitrogen and creatinine levels may indicate renal failure.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's increasing acidemia and hypoxemia may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.

Based on the patient's condition, further monitoring and management are necessary to address the patient's respiratory, cardiac, and metabolic status.

   mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   36yo male with morbid obesity was admitted s/p cardiac arrest at home.
   .
   1. s/p Arrest :  Unclear etiology.  Highest on the differential is PE
   given morbid obesity and sedentary lifestyle.  Additional differential
   diagnosis includes ischemia, which is not likely given no evidence on
   ECG, structural heart disease, and arrhythmia, although patient has no
   prior history of any of these abnormalities.  An additional possibility
   includes a non-cardiac cause of hemodynamic instability resulting in a
   PEA arrest, although patient has no specific localizing symptoms or
   signs.  Given patient's multiple medical problems including sleep
   apnea, asthma, and morbid obesity, a possible etiology of his arrest
   was arrest in the setting of hypoxia related to his
   obesity-hypoventilation, sleep apnea, and asthma, however less likely.
   ECG showed evidence of RSR
 IVCD and RV hypokinesis on ECHO yesterday
   consistent with possible PE.  Attempted to get a CTA to look for PE
   yesterday, however based on pts weight it was unable to be completed.
   - Artic Sun Cooling protocol with vecuronium, start rewarming today at
   1pm
   - Intubated, sedated
   - LENIs today
   - Treat with heparin empirically
   - replete electrolytes aggressively, checking electrolytes Q6H
   following rewarming
   - follow-up blood and urine cultures
   - Trend CK daily
   .
   2. Leukocytosis:   Etiology of his leukocytosis is most likely related
   to his Vfib arrest, although infection is also possible, given evidence
   of UTI on UA.  Trending down.
   - Treat with Cipro
   - follow-up blood cultures
   - follow-up CXR read
   .
   3. Morbid Obesity
   Patient has morbid obesity and is currently undergoing outpatient
   evaluation for gastric bypass.
   - continue outpatient evaluation for gastric bypass procedure
   .
   4. Respiratory Failure:  Patient was intubated in the setting of
   cardiac arrest ABG on current settings demonstrates adequate
   oxygenation but likely respiratory acidosis given slightly elevated
   PCO2.  No evidence of ARDS
   - continue to maintain intubation and sedation for adequate cooling
   .
   5. Transaminitis:  Improved
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient was intubated due to cardiac arrest, and his current ABG results indicate adequate oxygenation but likely respiratory acidosis given slightly elevated PCO2.
2. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis is likely related to his VFib arrest, although infection is also possible, given evidence of UTI on UA.
3. Transaminitis: The patient's transaminitis has improved.
4. Morbid obesity: The patient has morbid obesity and is currently undergoing outpatient evaluation for gastric bypass.
5. Unclear etiology of cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest is unclear, with a differential diagnosis including PE, ischemia, structural heart disease, and arrhythmia.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen if not properly managed, leading to further acidosis, hypoxia, and potential lung injury.
2. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and UTI diagnosis increase the risk of sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction and poor outcomes.
3. Venous thromboembolism (VTE): The patient's morbid obesity and immobility increase the risk of VTE, which can lead to pulmonary embolism and other complications.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's transaminitis and possible coagulopathy increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, which can be life-threatening.
5. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's unclear etiology of cardiac arrest and potential underlying cardiac disease increase the risk of cardiovascular instability, which can lead to further cardiac arrest or other cardiovascular complications.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Intubation and sedation for adequate cooling and respiratory support.
2. Empirical treatment with heparin for possible VTE.
3. Repletion of electrolytes aggressively, with frequent monitoring.
4. Follow-up blood and urine cultures to monitor for infection.
5. Trending of CK daily to monitor for possible cardiac injury.
6. Outpatient evaluation for gastric bypass procedure to address morbid obesity.

The patient's care will require close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiac, and metabolic status to prevent further complications and improve his outcomes.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 89 bpm, and blood pressure of 97/50 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is also stable, with a PEEP of 15 cmH2O and an FiO2 of 50%.

The patient's laboratory results show mild leukocytosis, likely due to a urinary tract infection (UTI). The patient is being treated with ciprofloxacin, and cultures are pending.

The patient's neurologic status is concerning, with an EEG showing diffuse slowing and no foci of activity. The patient is currently sedated, but the plan is to attempt weaning sedation today.

The patient's respiratory failure is being managed with mechanical ventilation, and the plan is to attempt weaning from sedation today and reassess the respiratory status.

The patient's morbid obesity is a significant concern, and the patient is undergoing outpatient evaluation for gastric bypass surgery.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but there is a risk of worsening hypoxia and hypercapnia if the patient's sedation is weaned too quickly.
2. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's cardiac arrest was likely caused by a PE, and there is a risk of further embolization if the patient's anticoagulation therapy is not adequate.
3. Urinary tract infection: The patient's leukocytosis is likely due to a UTI, and there is a risk of further complications if the infection is not adequately treated.
4. Neurologic damage: The patient's EEG shows diffuse slowing, which may indicate neurologic damage. There is a risk of further damage if the patient's sedation is weaned too quickly or if the patient experiences further cardiac arrest.
5. Morbid obesity-related complications: The patient's morbid obesity is a significant concern, and there is a risk of further complications if the patient does not lose weight or if the patient develops other obesity-related conditions, such as diabetes or hypertension.

Overall, the patient's condition is stable, but there are several potential medical complications that can arise if not adequately managed.

Summary:

The patient is a 36-year-old male with morbid obesity who was admitted to the ICU after cardiac arrest at home. He has been intubated and sedated, and is receiving mechanical ventilation. His current vital signs include a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 89 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 97/50 mmHg. He is receiving heparin for suspected pulmonary embolism, and his laboratory results show evidence of leukocytosis, transaminitis, and possible respiratory failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary Embolism (PE): The patient's cardiac arrest and evidence of RV hypokinesis on echocardiogram suggest a possible PE. Continued heparin therapy and close monitoring of his condition are necessary to prevent further complications.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is concerning, with evidence of hypoxia and hypercapnia. Weaning from sedation and mechanical ventilation will be crucial to prevent further complications.
3. Infectious Complications: The patient's leukocytosis and bloody sputum may indicate an infectious process, such as a urinary tract infection or pulmonary infarction. Cultures and antibiotic therapy should be continued to address these concerns.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and evidence of RV hypokinesis on echocardiogram suggest possible cardiac complications, such as cardiac tamponade or cardiogenic shock. Close monitoring of his cardiac status is necessary to prevent further complications.
5. Nutritional Complications: The patient's morbid obesity and current nutritional status may put him at risk for malnutrition and related complications. Close monitoring of his nutritional status and provision of adequate nutrition are necessary to prevent these complications.
6. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's transaminitis and possible respiratory failure may indicate gastrointestinal complications, such as aspiration or gastrointestinal bleeding. Close monitoring of his gastrointestinal status is necessary to prevent further complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue heparin therapy for suspected PE.
2. Wean sedation and mechanical ventilation as soon as possible to prevent respiratory failure.
3. Continue antibiotic therapy for possible infectious complications.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely to prevent cardiac complications.
5. Provide adequate nutrition to prevent malnutrition and related complications.
6. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status closely to prevent gastrointestinal complications.
7. Consider consulting with a pulmonologist or intensivist to optimize the patient's respiratory care.
8. Consider consulting with a cardiologist to optimize the patient's cardiac care.
9. Monitor the patient's laboratory results closely to detect any changes in his condition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 36-year-old male with morbid obesity who was admitted to the ICU after suffering a cardiac arrest at home. The patient has undergone various interventions, including weaning of vecuronium, warming of core temperature, and increased sedation.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* T-max: 37.4°C (normal)
* T-current: 37.4°C (normal)
* HR: 89 bpm (normal)
* BP: 97/50 mmHg (normal)
* RR: 28 breaths per minute (normal)
* SpO2: 100% (normal)
* Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm (normal)

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 8.5-11.3 K/μL (normal)
* Hct: 39.9-37.4% (normal)
* Plt: 155-199 K/μL (normal)
* Cr: 0.7-0.9 mg/dL (normal)
* TCO2: 22-25 mmHg (normal)
* Glucose: 92-104 mg/dL (normal)

The patient's medical history is significant for morbid obesity and a possible pulmonary embolism (PE), which is the highest differential diagnosis. The patient is receiving heparin for suspected PE and will have a D-dimer test done to confirm or rule out the diagnosis.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a PEEP of 15 cmH2O and an FiO2 of 50%. The patient is currently on a ventilator and is being weaned off sedation.

The patient's neurological status is stable, with a diffuse slowing on EEG. The patient is currently sedated and is unable to assess responsiveness. The plan is to wean sedation and reassess the patient's neurological status.

The patient's overall condition is stable, but there are potential medical complications that can arise. These include:

* Pulmonary embolism (PE): The patient is at risk for PE due to his morbid obesity and cardiac arrest. The patient is receiving heparin to prevent further clotting, but the diagnosis is not yet confirmed.
* Respiratory failure: The patient is on a ventilator and is at risk for respiratory failure. The patient's PEEP is 15 cmH2O, which is relatively high, and the FiO2 is 50%, which is relatively high as well.
* Neurological damage: The patient's EEG shows diffuse slowing, which may indicate neurological damage. The patient is currently sedated and is unable to assess responsiveness.
* Infection: The patient has a history of UTI and is at risk for further infection. The patient is receiving antibiotics for suspected UTI.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of morbid obesity and is at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient is receiving prophylaxis for stress ulcer.

Overall, the patient's condition is stable, but there are potential medical complications that can arise. The patient's care team should continue to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 36-year-old male with morbid obesity who was admitted to the ICU following a cardiac arrest at home. He is currently intubated and sedated, with a diagnosis of PE and respiratory failure. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 84 beats per minute, blood pressure of 145/64 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 94%. He is receiving propofol and fentanyl for sedation and has a D-dimer level of 1408 ng/mL, indicating a high risk of thrombotic events.

The patient's respiratory status is a concern, with hypoxia on CMV and failure to wean off PEEP. His chest X-ray shows fluid overload, and he is receiving lasix to help with diuresis. His blood cultures are pending, but his sputum culture shows oropharyngeal flora, which may indicate contamination.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels, which may indicate inflammation or tissue damage. His troponin-T level is elevated, indicating possible cardiac damage.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require further interventions to improve oxygenation.
2. Thrombotic events: The patient's D-dimer level is elevated, indicating a high risk of thrombotic events, such as deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.
3. Infection: The patient's sputum culture shows oropharyngeal flora, which may indicate contamination, and his blood cultures are pending. He may require further evaluation and treatment for possible infection.
4. Cardiac damage: The patient's troponin-T level is elevated, indicating possible cardiac damage. He may require further evaluation and treatment for possible cardiac complications.
5. Fluid overload: The patient's chest X-ray shows fluid overload, and he is receiving lasix to help with diuresis. He may require further evaluation and treatment for possible fluid overload.

Based on the patient's condition, the following plan of care is recommended:

1. Continue respiratory support with PEEP and FiO2 as needed to improve oxygenation.
2. Monitor the patient's D-dimer level and consider anticoagulation therapy to prevent thrombotic events.
3. Evaluate the patient's sputum culture and blood cultures to determine if infection is present.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and consider further evaluation and treatment for possible cardiac complications.
5. Monitor the patient's fluid status and consider further evaluation and treatment for possible fluid overload.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's laboratory results and adjust his treatment plan as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 36-year-old male with morbid obesity who was admitted to the ICU after a cardiac arrest at home. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 10 cmH2O and FiO2 of 50%. He has been weaned off sedation and is awake and responsive to commands. However, he remains hypoxic and requires ongoing respiratory support. He has a history of cardiac arrest and is being treated with heparin for potential PE. His lab results show elevated troponin and CK levels, indicating possible cardiac damage. He also has leukocytosis and transaminitis, which are being monitored.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxia and respiratory failure could worsen if his ventilation settings are not optimized or if he develops respiratory complications such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and elevated troponin and CK levels suggest possible cardiac damage. He may be at risk for further cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiogenic shock.
3. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and bloody sputum could indicate an underlying infection, such as pneumonia or sepsis. He may be at risk for developing further infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or catheter-related bloodstream infections.
4. Hemorrhagic complications: The patient's bleeding disorder and elevated PT and PTT levels could increase his risk for hemorrhagic complications, such as bleeding from his airway, gastrointestinal tract, or surgical site.
5. Nutritional complications: The patient's morbid obesity and need for prolonged mechanical ventilation may increase his risk for nutritional deficiencies, such as malnutrition or electrolyte imbalances.
6. Pressure ulcers: The patient's prolonged immobility and morbid obesity may increase his risk for developing pressure ulcers, which could lead to further complications such as infection, necrosis, or sepsis.

Based on this information, it is essential to continue monitoring the patient's respiratory, cardiac, and hemodynamic status closely and to adjust his treatment plan as needed to prevent and manage potential complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following information is summarized:

The patient is a 36-year-old male with morbid obesity who was admitted after a cardiac arrest at home. The cause of the cardiac arrest is unclear due to limitations in imaging provided by his body size. The patient has been diagnosed with possible pulmonary embolism (PE) based on ECG and echocardiogram findings. He is currently on heparin therapy and will continue to be monitored for PE.

The patient is also experiencing respiratory failure and is on assisted ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate of 26, and PEEP of 10 cmH2O. His oxygen saturation is 94% and his ABG shows a PO2 of 72. He is also experiencing increased sputum production, which may be due to ETT trauma or pulmonary infarction.

The patient has a history of leukocytosis, which is likely related to a urinary tract infection (UTI) and is being treated with ciprofloxacin. He also has transaminitis, which has improved.

The patient is currently on several medications, including fentanyl, propofol, pantoprazole, and furosemide. He has a central venous catheter and an arterial line in place.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and PE diagnosis make it a high-risk condition. Further monitoring and treatment are necessary to prevent recurrent PE.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and close monitoring is necessary to prevent further deterioration.
3. Sepsis: The patient's increased sputum production and leukocytosis may indicate a possible infection, which could lead to sepsis.
4. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and ongoing heparin therapy make it a high-risk condition.
5. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's morbid obesity and ongoing medical treatment may lead to nutritional deficiencies, which need to be monitored and addressed.
6. Wound complications: The patient's increased sputum production may lead to wound complications, such as pneumonia or empyema.

Based on the patient's condition, it is recommended that he be closely monitored for any signs of deterioration and that his treatment plan be adjusted accordingly.

Summary:

The patient is a 36-year-old male with morbid obesity who was admitted to the ICU after a cardiac arrest at home. He is currently intubated and sedated. His condition is stable, but he is still hypoxic on continuous mandatory ventilation (CMV) with a PEEP of 10 cmH2O and FiO2 of 50%. His blood pressure is stable, and his heart rate is within normal limits. His respiratory status is improving, but he is still producing a significant amount of dark brown sputum, which may be due to ETT trauma or pulmonary infarction.

The patient has a D-dimer positive result, indicating the possibility of a pulmonary embolism (PE). He is receiving heparin for this potential diagnosis and will have his D-dimer levels checked again to determine if the result is negative. His cardiac enzymes are elevated, indicating possible cardiac damage.

The patient's neurologic status is stable, but he is currently sedated and unable to assess his responsiveness. He will be weaned from sedation today and his respiratory status will be reassessed.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 9.3 K/uL, which may indicate a possible urinary tract infection (UTI). He is being treated with Ciprofloxacin and his cultures are pending.

The patient's morbid obesity is a significant concern, and he is undergoing outpatient evaluation for gastric bypass surgery.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary Embolism (PE): The patient's D-dimer positive result and elevated cardiac enzymes indicate the possibility of a PE, which can lead to respiratory failure and death if not treated promptly.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's hypoxic status and increased sputum production may indicate respiratory failure, which can lead to further complications such as pneumonia and sepsis.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and positive D-dimer result may indicate the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ failure and death if not treated promptly.
4. Cardiac Damage: The patient's elevated cardiac enzymes may indicate cardiac damage, which can lead to further complications such as cardiac arrhythmias and heart failure.
5. Pneumonia: The patient's dark brown sputum production may indicate the possibility of pneumonia, which can lead to further complications such as respiratory failure and sepsis.
6. UTI: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and positive culture results may indicate the possibility of a UTI, which can lead to further complications such as sepsis and kidney damage.
7. Gastric Bypass Complications: The patient's morbid obesity and upcoming gastric bypass surgery may increase the risk of complications such as bleeding, infection, and respiratory failure.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a diagnosis of hypoxic respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation. They have been weaned off sedation, but remain hypoxic on continuous mandatory ventilation (CMV) with a PEEP of 10 cmH2O. The patient's D-dimer is positive, and they have increased sputum production with dark brown color and GPCs from the ET tube. The patient's laboratory results show anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated lactate levels. They are receiving fentanyl and propofol for sedation and pain management.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxia and need for mechanical ventilation put them at risk for respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's positive D-dimer and increased sputum production with dark brown color and GPCs from the ET tube suggest the possibility of sepsis.
3. Bleeding: The patient's thrombocytopenia and elevated lactate levels increase their risk of bleeding.
4. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's anemia and hypoxia may lead to cardiovascular instability.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's sedation and mechanical ventilation increase their risk of neurological complications such as brain injury or stroke.
6. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's altered nutrition and glycemic control may lead to nutritional deficiencies.
7. Venous thromboembolism (VTE): The patient's immobility and increased risk of bleeding make them susceptible to VTE.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as necessary.
2. Consider further evaluation for sepsis, including blood cultures and imaging studies.
3. Monitor the patient's bleeding risk and adjust anticoagulation therapy as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and adjust therapy as necessary.
5. Consider neurological monitoring and prophylactic measures to prevent neurological complications.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's nutritional status and adjust nutrition therapy as necessary.
7. Consider VTE prophylaxis and monitor the patient's risk factors for VTE.

Summary:

The patient, a 36-year-old male with morbid obesity, is currently in the ICU following a cardiac arrest at home, likely due to a pulmonary embolism (PE). He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 10 cmH2O and FiO2 of 50%. His sedation has been weaned, and he is responsive to commands, but still hypoxic. He has a history of leukocytosis, which is trending down, and is being treated with Ciprofloxacin for a suspected urinary tract infection (UTI). His D-dimer is positive, and he has dark brown sputum production with Gram-positive cocci (GPCs) from the endotracheal tube (ETT), but the culture is negative for oropharyngeal flora.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxia may worsen if his PEEP is decreased or if he develops respiratory acidosis.
2. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and positive D-dimer may indicate an underlying infection, which could lead to sepsis.
3. Thrombosis: The patient's morbid obesity and history of PE may increase his risk of developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anticoagulation therapy and history of morbid obesity may increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's morbid obesity and ICU stay may lead to nutritional deficiencies, particularly vitamin D and calcium deficiencies.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and PE may increase his risk of developing cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's sedation and mechanical ventilation may increase his risk of developing neurological complications, such as seizures or brain injury.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his PEEP and FiO2 accordingly.
2. Consider increasing the patient's anticoagulation therapy to prevent further thrombotic events.
3. Monitor the patient's nutritional status and provide adequate caloric and vitamin supplements as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust his medication regimen as needed.
5. Consider weaning the patient's sedation and extubating him if he remains stable and responsive.
6. Monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust his sedation regimen as needed to prevent further neurological complications.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 36-year-old male with morbid obesity who was admitted to the ICU after a cardiac arrest at home. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation and has been receiving tube feeds.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 66 bpm, blood pressure of 106/62 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a central venous pressure of 18 mmHg, and fluid balance shows a total input of 2,334 mL and a total output of 4,060 mL over the past 24 hours.

The patient's physical examination reveals a morbidly obese male who is responsive to commands and has normal S1/S2 heart sounds. The patient's chest is clear, and there is no evidence of chest wall deformities or scoliosis. The patient's abdomen is soft and non-tender, and there is no evidence of pedal edema.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 9.3 K/uL, hemoglobin of 11.7 g/dL, and platelet count of 204 K/uL. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, and his blood urea nitrogen and creatinine levels are slightly elevated.

The patient's imaging studies show a chest X-ray with signs of fluid overload, ascites, and small left pleural effusion. The patient's electroencephalogram shows diffuse slowing while on sedation, but the patient is responsive to commands.

The patient's plan includes continued weaning of sedation and mechanical ventilation, with the goal of extubation. The patient will also continue to receive tube feeds and antibiotics for a total of 10 days. The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is ICU for now.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation, and there is a risk of respiratory failure if the patient is not weaned off the ventilator successfully.
* Infection: The patient has leukocytosis and is at risk of developing an infection, particularly in the setting of a urinary tract infection.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest, and there is a risk of cardiovascular complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of morbid obesity and is at risk of developing gastrointestinal complications, such as gastroesophageal reflux disease or pancreatitis.
* Venous thromboembolism: The patient is at risk of developing a venous thromboembolism, particularly in the setting of immobility and obesity.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and manage potential complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following information can be summarized:

The patient, a 36-year-old male with morbid obesity, was admitted to the ICU following a cardiac arrest at home, likely due to a pulmonary embolism (PE). He was initially sedated and intubated, and his respiratory status was complicated by hypoxia, requiring increased PEEP and FiO2. His neurological status is being monitored, and he is currently unable to respond due to sedation. His laboratory results show elevated troponin-T, CK, and CKMB levels, consistent with cardiac injury.

The patient's respiratory status remains a concern, with a CXR showing signs of fluid overload and small pleural effusions. He is currently receiving diuretic therapy and will continue to be monitored for fluid overload. His bleeding from the endotracheal tube (ETT) is likely due to ETT trauma and anticoagulation.

The patient's leukocytosis is trending down, and he is being treated for a possible urinary tract infection (UTI). His transaminitis has improved.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains a concern, and he may require further interventions to improve oxygenation.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac injury may lead to further complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure.
3. Infection: The patient's UTI and possible ETT trauma may increase his risk of infection.
4. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid overload may worsen if not managed appropriately.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's sedation and intubation may lead to neurological complications, such as seizures or cognitive impairment.
6. Bleeding complications: The patient's bleeding from the ETT may worsen if not managed appropriately.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's morbid obesity and potential gastric bypass surgery may increase his risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or obstruction.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 36-year-old male with morbid obesity who was admitted to the ICU after a cardiac arrest at home, likely secondary to a pulmonary embolism (PE) causing primary respiratory arrest. He is currently on mechanical ventilation with a peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) of 26 cmH2O, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 10 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 66 beats per minute, blood pressure of 106/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 96%. His respiratory rate is 28 inspirations per minute, and his temperature is 36.5°C.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 9.3 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin of 11.7 g/dL, and platelet count of 204 x 10^9/L. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated potassium level of 4.2 mmol/L. His lactate level is 1.2 mmol/L, and his troponin-T level is 0.46 ng/mL.

The patient's imaging studies show a small left pleural effusion and retrocardiac atelectasis on chest radiography (CXR). His electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a sinus rhythm with a heart rate of 66 beats per minute.

The patient's clinical status is stable, but he has several potential complications that need to be monitored and managed. These include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation, and his oxygenation is trending downward. He may require further increases in PEEP and FiO2 to maintain adequate oxygenation.
2. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiac arrest may have caused damage to his heart, and he may be at risk for further cardiac complications.
3. Neurological impairment: The patient's EEG shows diffuse slowing, which may indicate a degree of neurological impairment.
4. Sepsis: The patient has a leukocytosis and a positive blood culture, which may indicate the presence of sepsis.
5. Morbid obesity: The patient's morbid obesity may increase his risk of developing complications such as pressure ulcers, respiratory failure, and cardiovascular disease.

In summary, the patient is a 36-year-old male with morbid obesity who was admitted to the ICU after a cardiac arrest at home. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and has several potential complications that need to be monitored and managed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 36-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU following cardiac arrest at home, likely secondary to a pulmonary embolism (PE) causing primary respiratory arrest. He has been diagnosed with morbid obesity and is undergoing outpatient evaluation for gastric bypass.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Sedation was decreased, and he appears responsive to commands.
* He is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 10 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%.
* His oxygenation trended down on 7 PEEP, so he was put back on 10 cmH2O with better oxygenation.
* He received diuresis with furosemide (Lasix) and has a negative fluid balance of 1,726 mL over the past 24 hours.
* He has a leukocytosis of 9.3 K/uL, which may be due to a urinary tract infection (UTI) on urinalysis (UA).
* His troponin-T level is 0.46 ng/mL, which is elevated but trending down.
* He has a CXR showing signs of fluid overload, ascites, and a small left pleural effusion.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's oxygenation is still a concern, and he may require further adjustments to his ventilator settings.
* Infection: The patient's leukocytosis may be due to a UTI, and he may require further antibiotics.
* Pulmonary embolism: The patient's history of PE and the presence of a small left pleural effusion on CXR suggest that he may be at risk for further pulmonary embolism.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac arrest history and elevated troponin-T level suggest that he may be at risk for cardiac arrhythmias.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's morbid obesity and history of gastric bypass surgery may increase his risk for gastrointestinal complications such as bleeding, perforation, or obstruction.
* Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's tube feeds may not be providing adequate nutrition, and he may require further evaluation and management of his nutritional status.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiac, and infectious disease status.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information:

The patient is a 36-year-old male with morbid obesity who was admitted to the ICU after suffering a cardiac arrest at home. The arrest was likely caused by a pulmonary embolism (PE) leading to primary respiratory arrest. The patient has been extubated and is currently receiving CPAP therapy at night and non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) during the day.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 87 beats per minute, blood pressure of 141/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100% on 60% fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2). The patient's respiratory rate is 21 breaths per minute, and his cardiac rhythm is normal sinus rhythm.

The patient's laboratory results show mild elevation in creatinine (0.9 mg/dL) and mild anemia (11.9 g/dL). His white blood cell count is 8.1 x 10^9/L, and his platelet count is 199 x 10^9/L.

The patient is receiving various medications, including heparin, warfarin, nitroprusside, metoprolol, and hydralazine. He is also receiving antibiotics for a urinary tract infection (UTI) and is undergoing outpatient evaluation for gastric bypass surgery.

The patient's plan of care includes weaning off nitroprusside, adding captopril and spironolactone for hypertension, and continuing Cipro for 10 days for UTI. The patient is also scheduled to undergo gastric bypass surgery.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk for respiratory failure due to his morbid obesity and history of cardiac arrest.
2. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is elevated, and he is at risk for developing hypertension-related complications.
3. UTI: The patient has a UTI, and there is a risk of developing antibiotic-resistant bacteria.
4. DVT: The patient is at risk for developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to his immobility and history of cardiac arrest.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's morbid obesity increases his risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as gastric perforation or obstruction.

Overall, the patient's condition appears to be stable, but he requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

   .

   however pt is responsive when sedation is weaned.
   - Artic Sun Cooling protocol completed.
   - Discontinue all sedating medications in an attempt to wean off vent
   .

   concern. Increased PEEP and FiO2.

   over past two days.

   .

   suggest infection. Will monitor.
   - F/u Cultures
   .
   # Leukocytosis:   Most likely in the setting of UTI on UA.  Trending
   down.
   - Continue Cipro, for total of 10 days
   -  cultures: NGTD
   .
   # Morbid Obesity: Patient has morbid obesity and is currently
   undergoing outpatient evaluation for gastric bypass.
   - continue outpatient evaluation for gastric bypass procedure

Summary:

The patient is a 36-year-old male with morbid obesity who was admitted to the ICU following cardiac arrest at home, likely secondary to a pulmonary embolism (PE) causing primary respiratory arrest. He was extubated and initiated on CPAP, but it was discontinued and replaced with nebulizers to maintain SaO2 in the low 90s. He received hydralazine and metoprolol for hypertension, and nitroprusside was started for blood pressure control. He is currently on CPAP/PSV with a FiO2 of 60% and PEEP of 5 cmH2O. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 87 bpm, blood pressure of 141/62 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute. He is alert and oriented to year and hospital, but has leukocytosis and is being monitored for potential infections.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is a concern, as he is still on CPAP/PSV and has a history of respiratory failure. Weaning attempts may be challenging, and he may require further respiratory support.
2. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is still elevated, and further management with antihypertensive medications may be necessary to control his blood pressure.
3. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis may indicate a potential infection, and further evaluation and treatment may be necessary to prevent complications.
4. Morbid Obesity: The patient's morbid obesity is a significant risk factor for various medical complications, including respiratory and cardiovascular issues. His ongoing evaluation for gastric bypass surgery may help mitigate these risks.
5. Pneumonia: The patient's bloody sputum may indicate a potential pneumonia, which could worsen his respiratory status and increase the risk of complications.
6. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient's history of cardiac arrest and prolonged immobility may increase his risk of developing a DVT, which could lead to serious complications if left untreated.
7. Stress Ulcer: The patient's critical illness and use of anticoagulation medications may increase his risk of developing a stress ulcer, which could lead to bleeding complications.
8. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): The patient's prolonged use of mechanical ventilation may increase his risk of developing VAP, which could worsen his respiratory status and increase the risk of complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 36-year-old male with morbid obesity who was admitted after a cardiac arrest at home. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation in the ICU. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 87 beats per minute, blood pressure of 141/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%. He is extubated and responding to commands. His respiratory status is improving, with a respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute and a partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 160 mmHg.

The patient has a history of hypertension, which is being managed with nitroprusside and metoprolol. He also has a urinary tract infection (UTI), which is being treated with ciprofloxacin. His neurologic status is improving after weaning sedation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but he is still at risk for respiratory failure due to his morbid obesity and underlying lung disease.
2. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is still elevated, and he is at risk for complications such as cardiac failure, stroke, and kidney damage if it is not adequately controlled.
3. UTI: The patient's UTI is being treated with ciprofloxacin, but he is at risk for developing antibiotic-resistant bacteria and recurrent infections if the infection is not fully treated.
4. Morbid obesity: The patient's morbid obesity is a risk factor for various complications, including respiratory failure, cardiovascular disease, and metabolic disorders.
5. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest is still a risk factor for cardiac complications, including arrhythmias, cardiac failure, and death.
6. Neurologic complications: The patient's neurologic status is improving, but he is at risk for complications such as seizures, stroke, and brain damage if he experiences another cardiac arrest or develops a severe infection.
7. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for developing sepsis due to his UTI and other underlying infections, which can lead to organ failure and death.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his mechanical ventilation settings as needed to ensure optimal oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Continue to manage the patient's hypertension with nitroprusside and metoprolol, and consider adding other antihypertensive medications as needed to control his blood pressure.
3. Continue to treat the patient's UTI with ciprofloxacin for a total of 10 days, and consider adding other antibiotics as needed to ensure optimal treatment.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's neurologic status and adjust his sedation and analgesia as needed to ensure optimal comfort and minimize the risk of neurologic complications.
5. Consider referring the patient to a cardiologist or other specialist for further evaluation and management of his cardiac arrest and underlying cardiac disease.
6. Consider referring the patient to a nutritionist or other healthcare professional for further evaluation and management of his morbid obesity and related complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 36-year-old male with morbid obesity who was admitted to the ICU after suffering a cardiac arrest at home, likely secondary to a pulmonary embolism (PE) causing primary respiratory arrest. He has been receiving heparin and warfarin for anticoagulation. His neurologic status has improved after weaning sedation. He is currently extubated and receiving non-invasive ventilation at night and CPAP during the day.

He has a history of hypertension, which is being managed with nitroprusside, captopril, and spironolactone. He also has a urinary tract infection (UTI) for which he is receiving Ciprofloxacin for 10 days. He is undergoing outpatient evaluation for gastric bypass surgery.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 87 bpm, and blood pressure of 150/60 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 27 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 97%. He has thick secretions and requires non-invasive ventilation.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is precarious, and he may require further respiratory support.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac arrest may have caused cardiac damage, leading to arrhythmias.
3. Sepsis: The patient's UTI and thick secretions may lead to sepsis.
4. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's morbid obesity and immobility make him prone to DVT.
5. Stress ulcer: The patient's ICU stay and sedation may increase his risk of stress ulcer.
6. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's non-invasive ventilation and thick secretions may increase his risk of VAP.
7. Gastric bypass complications: The patient's upcoming gastric bypass surgery may be complicated by his morbid obesity and ICU stay.

These complications will need to be closely monitored and managed to ensure the patient's optimal care.
